titleInfo.title: 47MN3 Mouse Creek Site 4MN3, McMinn County, Tennessee. Feature 9, Dwelling house floor pattern with center hearth. Feature 11, Firebasin lies in upper left hand corner of photograph; a stone metate lies close to the central firebasin on the floor of Feature 9. Entryway appears at the south corner of the southeast wall

mods.abstract: [Feature 9] The house was located close to the creek bank which is quite heavily grown in trees and shrubs. For this reason it was not considered feasible to remove this growth and excavate over the break of the bank. Thus the north end of the house was not excavated. Since the house was apparently considerably longer than wide probably 1/4 of the house was not excavated. The humus accumulation over the house was relatively thick (average 1.5' - 2.0') and the entire area penetrated by numerous roots. Irregular, scattered remnants of a pit outline were apparent -- but the pit was quite shallow with no suggestion of vertical walls. In general the extent of the house was determined by the post molds. The floor of the house was slightly depressed. Two fire basins were in the floor of the house. One in the northwest end is discussed as Feature 11. The other occupied the approximate center of the structure. It was a moderately shallow basin -- bowl shaped with a rather low, rounded curbing of puddled clay circular in aspect. The curbing was 0.1' - 0.2' above the general floor level, and 0.3 above the bottom of the basin. A large quantity of grass, cane, and wood impressed wattle lay over the center of the house 0.3' - 0.5' above the floor and separated from the floor by a thin layer of loose black humic soil. Other scattered patches of wattle lay outside the central mass of wattle. The entry trenches in the characteristic shape (n) penetrated the southeast wall near the south corner. Fairly extensive areas of compacted, burned clay surrounding Feature 11 and the central fire basin were recognizable as floor. These merged with the general unburned compacted floor. The remainder of the floor was compacted and of mottled hue -- the post molds fairly distinct where root disturbances did not interfere. The actual "fill" of the shallow house area was characteristically mixed -- the thick humic band above, however, which bore the interferring vegetation was comparatively sterile and a uniform black in color. This house appears abberant in its dimensions, however, it may not have been a great deal longer from northwest to southeast thus minimizing its oblong appearance. There is a faint suggestion of an orderly pattern for the interior post molds of the structure -- however, the observer may draw his own conclusions by referring to the large scale plot. [Feature 11] Fire basin, probably accessory on floor of Feature 9 -- circular -- straight sides -- rim partly modelled and curbed. Two fire basins are represented under this feature. Basin II is the latest and overlaps half of Basin I to the north. In order of construction Basin I was dug about 0.2' deeper than Basin II, it had almost vertical sides which curved in slightly to join the bottom - no evidence of curbing at the rim which apparently was flush with the floor. Basin I was abandoned and filled with Basin II constructed so as to overlap the south half of Basin I. The deeper overlapping portion of I was filled with ash and modelled to fill the breach at the overlap and Basin I apparently was forgotten as the burned floor was about 0.1' - 0.2' thick above it. A thin, fragile, rounded curbing was built around the top of Basin I and it was appparently used contemporaneously with Feature 9. Basin I was about half-full of gray, soft ash which cleaved away easily from the hard packed and burned ash forming the north half of the bottom of Basin II. The sides are almost vertical rounding inward to merge with the bottom.
